snippet: Workers and students, enticed by the start of spring, took their laptops and ideas outside so they could soak in the balmy weather.
abstract: Busy professionals and college students across New York City take advantage of a balmy first day of spring to hold meetings and study sessions outdoors.

headline.main: In Sun’s Glow, It’s Still Business, but Not as Usual
headline.print_headline: In Sun’s Glow, It’s Still Business, but Not as Usual

snippet: With the Barclays Center arena set to open in September, property owners in the area remain uncertain about the rest of the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn.
abstract: Barclays Center arena is set to open later this year, but property owners in the area remain uncertain about the rest of the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn; landlords are being cautious about long-term leases as they wait with what can be described as optimistic uncertainty about what the project will do for real estate prices, and how the neighborhood will be shaped.

headline.main: In Barclays Center’s Shadow, Awaiting What’s Next
headline.print_headline: In Barclays Center’s Shadow, Awaiting What’s Next

snippet: Two different reports found that the new iPad can become hotter than the iPad 2 during heavy use. Apple said that the new iPad works within its thermal specifications.
abstract: Two different reports found that the new iPad can become hotter than the iPad 2 during heavy use. Apple said that the new iPad works within its thermal specifications.

headline.main: Taking the Temperature of the New iPad

snippet: Hewlett-Packard will merge its personal computer and printing divisions in an effort to cut costs, improve designs and gain efficiency, the company announced.
abstract: Hewlett-Packard announces that it will merge its personal computer and printing divisions in an effort to cut costs, improve designs and gain efficiency; consolidation is the first major strategic move since Meg Whitman became chief executive in 2011.

headline.print_headline: H.P. Is Said to Be Poised To Merge Business Units

snippet: Tuesday's selections include robots that will ease the demand on their human co-workers in Amazon's warehouses and Apple response to reports that the new iPad gets hotter than previous versions.
abstract: Tuesday's selections include robots that will ease the demand on their human co-workers in Amazon's warehouses and Apple response to reports that the new iPad gets hotter than previous versions.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Humane Robots and Hot iPads

snippet: In an article in Harvard Business Review, Walter Isaacson says Mr. Jobs’s “petulance and impatience were part and parcel of his perfectionism.”
abstract: In an article in Harvard Business Review, Walter Isaacson says Mr. Jobs’s “petulance and impatience were part and parcel of his perfectionism.”

headline.main: Do You Have to Be Rude to Manage Like Steve Jobs?

snippet: Stock market indexes faltered after reports out of China raised concerns about its growth and amid worries over the high price of oil.
abstract: Stocks market indexes decline, ending a three-day advance for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, as commodities fell on concerns about a Chinese economic showdown.

headline.main: Shares Fall on Concerns of a Slowdown in China
headline.print_headline: Shares Fall on Concerns Of a Slowdown in China

snippet: Considering the revelation that parts of Mike Daisey's "The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs" were fabricated: Is there a "narrative truth" that transcends literal truth, or is truth always the most important thing?
abstract: Considering the revelation that parts of Mike Daisey's "The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs" were fabricated: Is there a "narrative truth" that transcends literal truth, or is truth always the most important thing?

headline.main: Where Is the Line Between Truth and Fiction?

snippet: When Google included smaller Web sites in the fees it charges to incorporate its maps online, many of them rebelled.
abstract: Google Maps is the dominant player in the world of street maps, satellite photos and street-level views; its new policy of charging smaller Web sites fees when their users start generating an average of 25,000 map views daily is causing many sites to rebel; 52 million people accessed maps on their smartphones in January, up 67 percent from year earlier.

headline.main: Facing Fees, Some Sites Are Bypassing Google Maps
headline.print_headline: Facing Fees, Some Sites Are Bypassing Google Maps

snippet: In “The Idea Factory,” Jon Gertner profiles Bell Labs in its heyday and the scientists whose unhurried pursuit of pure research led it to innovations that define modern life.
abstract: Michiko Kakutani reviews book The Idea Factory: Bell Labs and the Great Age of American Innovation by Jon Gertner.

headline.main: What Hath Bell Labs Wrought? The Future
headline.print_headline: What Hath Bell Labs Wrought? The Future
